item.title: PLOS One publication: The advantages of lexicon-based sentiment analysis in an age of machine learning.
item.description: A core feature of Covering Muslims is the analysis of how positive/negative newspaper coverage of Muslim is. Performing this analysis requires a robust, fine-grained sentiment analysis method. Since we were unable to find an existing method that proved acceptable for our purposes, we developed our own, MultiLexScaled, which uses multiple sentiment lexica, calibrated and scaled on a representative corpus of newspaper articles. The paper introducing the method, long available in preprint form, has now found an official published home at the general science journal PLOS One.

item.title: Critical Dialogue: Covering Muslims & The Struggle for Inclusion
item.description: Perspectives on Politics, a journal of the American Political Science Association, published a back and forth review-and-response Critical Dialogue between us and Elisabeth Ivarsflaten and Paul M. Sniderman, authors of the superb study The Struggle for Inclusion: Muslim Minorities and the Democratic Ethos (Chicago, 2022). As we wrote in our response to their review, “Juxtaposing the findings of our two books leads to a host of compelling research questions. We look forward to further research that enriches our understanding of the interactions between media coverage and public attitudes toward Muslims and other marginalized groups.

item.description: The Migration Policy Centre at the European University Institute maintains a valuable blog featuring articles about issues relevant to migrants and migration. We were invited to contributed a post, which appeared on May 30th. In it, we discuss the overall negativity of the media’s coverage of Muslims, and argue for the importance of “tone-checking” such coverage: consciously reflecting on the text of articles in order to develop an awareness of biases and errors.

item.title: Back to School with Maz Jobrani
item.description: In his Axis of Evil Comedy tour, Maz Jobrani tells a joke that nicely encapsulates a central problem with American media coverage of Muslims. item.title: The page 99 test
item.description: Marshal Zeringue (@zeringuemarshal) maintains a blog in which he asks authors of books to take Ford Madox Ford’s “page 99 test” and write about the results.
